msgSnippet: I have to agree with Mike. Test Mentor is a great product, and if you want support and you want it now, then the best thing to do is buy a commercial product

X-Sender: blaird@...
X-Apparently-To: junit@yahoogroups.com

Received: from unknown (HELO maex02.security.com) (216.57.147.6) by mta1 with SMTP; 11 Jul 2001 15:12:57 -0000

Message-ID: <F51E77692CD3D31190F300508B8BFA5E011E7E42@...>
To: "'junit@yahoogroups.com'" <junit@yahoogroups.com>
Subject: RE: [junit] Support for JUnit
Date: Wed, 11 Jul 2001 11:30:29 -0400
MIME-Version: 1.0
X-Mailer: Internet Mail Service (5.5.2653.19)
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"
From: "Laird, William" <blaird@...>

I have to agree with Mike. Test Mentor is a great product, and if you want
support and you want it now, then the best thing to do is buy a commercial
product that is based on JUnit. But as always, the net would make an
outstanding secondary resource. 

-----Original Message-----
From: Michael Silverstein [mailto:msilverstein@...]
Sent: Tuesday, July 10, 2001 10:53 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: RE: [junit] Support for JUnit


Not to intrude but if phone support, etc. is an issue for your organization
there's always the possibility of purchasing a commercial tool with
guaranteed support, training, etc. Test Mentor has a bunch of cool stuff for
component testing, such as code coverage metrics and test generation, and
runs JUnit tests as well. More information/download at www.silvermark.com.
We'll also be demonstrating the tool and presenting
http://www.extremeprogramming.org/xpu/papers/final/Paper36.pdf at XP
Universe in a few weeks.

^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
Mike Silverstein
SilverMark, Inc.
The object testing company
http://www.silvermark.com

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Penny Heatherington [mailto:pheatherington@...]
> Sent: Tuesday, July 10, 2001 5:59 PM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [junit] Support for JUnit
>
>
> My company has started to use JUnit as a testing tool for our
> Java development. We are considering making it an
> 'organizationally approved' tool for our development environment.
>  In order to accomplish this, we will perform a technical
> evaluation of the tool and submit an 'to be approved'
> recommendation to our Standards Committee. A 'Support Plan' must
> accompany the request for approval.  Consequently, I am
> researching support that is available for the tool.
>
> Do you have any specific information regarding JUnit support?
> Have any articles been written on the subject? Has a "Support
> Plan" been written by one of Junit's users.
>
> I have visited the SourceForge site as well as JUnit.org, so I am
> generally familiar with what is there.
>
> Does anyone provide telephone support?
>
> Thank you for any information you can provide.
>
> Penny Heatherington
> Project Lead
> OppenheimerFunds
>
>
